body.div:
"Dear, dear Elizabeth"I exclaimed
when I had read her letter"–Iwill write
instantlyand relieve them from the
great painthey must feel."
I wrote, and this exertion greatly
fatigued me ; b y ut
my convalescence
was
had
commencedand
went on
proceeded
regularly–in
another fortnight I was able to
leave my chamber.
______
Chap. 8
one of my first duties on my recovery was
to introduce Clerval to the
^
several
professors of
the university. And in doing thisI under
went torments a kind of rough usage
that ill befitten befitt ed ing
the wounds that
my mind had sustained. Ever since the
fatal night –the end of my labours &
thebeginning of my misfortunes (
I had
conceived a violent antipathy even to
the name of
Ch Chemistry Natural Philosophy .When I was other
wise quite restored to healththe sight of a
Chemical instrument brought on
again renewed
all
^
the agony of my my
^ nervous symtoms. Lo
Henry saw thisand had
p packed up removed
all my
machines in a chest apparatus from my
che view
he had also
changed my
room ap p artment,
for he perceived that
I had
a acquired
dislike tothe room which had
previously been my workshop.But these
cares of Clerval were
thrown away made of no avail
when
I visited the professors. even my excellent
M. Waldman inflicted torture when
he praisedwith the kindness and warmth,
the astonishing progress that I had made
in the sciences. He soon perceived
my
that I
dislike d of the subject, butnot guessing
the real causehe attributed
to it
my feelings
to modesty on hearing myself praised
he therefore
and changed the subject from
my improvement,to the science itself,
with an a desireas I evidently saw
of drawing friend me out.
K Kind
friend he tortured me without but
it How cruel is What could I do?
He meant to please and me & he
tortured
tormented
me it was
I felt as if he had
placed carefullyone by one placed in my
view those instruments which were
to be afterwards used in putting me to a
slow and cruel dre death. I writhed
under his words, yet dared not shew
my the pain I felt. Clerval, whose
eyes and feelings were always quick
in di s cerningthe sensations of others
declined the subject alledging in
^
his
ignorance& the conversation took
a more general turn. I thanked him
from my heart, but I did not speak.
I plainly sawthat he was surprised,
but he never attempted to draw
my secret from me,and although
I loved him with a mixture of
love
affection
and reverence that knew no
bounds,yet I could never
pr persuade
myself to confide to him that event
which was so often present to my
thoughts,but which I feared the detail
to another would only impress more deeply.
M r .Krempe was not
^
equally
docile yet & weak
asmy illness had made me
in my then
conditionof
almost in
supportable
sensitiveness
his harsh
blunt econiumsgave me even more
pain that than the benevolent
approbation of M. Waldman —"Dam m n
"the fellow,"cried he "Why M r . Clerval
"I tellyou he has beaut outstript
"us all– aystare if you pleasebut
"itis nevertheless true –A youngster
"whobut two threeyears agobelieved
"Cornelius Agrippa
to be
^
as firmly as the
gospelhas
"nowset himself at the head of
"the university& if he is not soon
"pulled downwe shall all be out
"of countenance.—Aye, Aye,continued
"heobserving my
countenance
^
face
ex
pressive of suffering "Mr. f Franken
stein is modestan excellent quality in
"ayoung man;Young men should be
"diffidentof themselvesyou know M
" Clerval;I was myself when youngbut
"one soon growsout of that."
M
Krempe had now commenced
the subject of his own praise an eulogy on himself and that
happily turned the conversation
from thesubject that was so
painful agonizing
to me.
Clerval was no natural philosopher.
His imagination was too vividfor
the minutiæ of science.
La Lan
guages
were his
chief
^
principal study for he
wished toopen a field for
^
him
self-instruc
tion
on his return – Greek Persian
& Arabic & Hebrew gainedhis atten
tion
when
X
so soon as X
he had become perfect
ly
master of the Greek & Latin langua
ges. For my own partidleness had
ever been irksome to meand
now that I wished tofly from reflec
tion and hated my former studies
a
I foundgreat relief in being the
fellow pupil of
with my fr friendand
I not a only found
instruct not only
instruc
tion but consolation in the works of
the orientalists. There is something soothing
Their melancholy is soothingand their
joy elevatingto a degree I never before
experienced in
reading
^
studying
any
^
the authors of any
other
books.
^
country.
When you read
s their
li writingslife
appears to consist in a warm sun
and gardensof roses – inthe smiles &
tears
frowns of a fair enemyand the fire
that consumes your own heart
How different from the man
^
l y& warlike
heroical
poet
ry
of Greece & Rome.
Summer passed away in these
studies
occupations
& my return to Geneva was
fixed for the latter end of Autum m n
but
being delayed by several accidentswinter
& snow arrived, and the roads were
deemed impassableand my
return
^
journey
delayed
was
retarted untillthe
^
ensuing
spring. I felt this
delay very bitterly
^
for I longed to see my
native
c t ownand my beloved friends
and my return had only been delayed
so longfrom an unwillingness to leave
Clerval in a strange townbefore he
had become acquainted with its in
habitants.The winter
^
however
was
however
s spent
a cheerful ly one and although the
spring was uncommonly latewhen
it cameits beauty compensated
for its dilatoriness. Ma The month
of May wasalready finis end com
pleated,and I expected daily the
letter thatwas to fix the date of
my
return
^
departure,
When Henry proposed
a pedestrian tour in environs of
Ingolstadtthat I might bid farewell
to the country I had so long in
habited.–I acceededwith pleasure to
this propos al
^
ition –I was fond of Exercise
and Clerval had always been my
favourite companion in
j
^
the
rambles
of this nature that I had taken
among the scenes of my native coun
try.We passed a fortnight in these
perambulations.My health and spirits had long
been restoredand they gained add i it ional vigour
from the salubrious air , X
I breathed,
X
the natural
incidents of
our progress X
and the
conversation of my friend. Study had before
renderedme unsocia ble l, –I had shunnedthe face
companyof my fellow beingsBut Clerval
called forth the better feelings of my heart.
he again taught me to love the aspect
of natureand the cheerful faces of chil
dren.Excellent Friend! How sincerely did you
love meand endeavour to elevate my
mind untillit was on a level with
your own.A selfish persuit e had cramp
ed and narrowed
it
^
me untillyour gentle
ness& affection warmed & opened
it
^
my senses . and
now I
^
now
became the same happy creature
whoa few years ago, loving& beloved by
all, had no sorrow or care – I and when
happy so
soul was more fitted than mine
for feeling delight in inanimate nature
X
X had the
power of
bes
bo towing on
me the most
delightful
sensations —
A serene sky filled and verdant
s fields
filled me with extasy.– t T he
^
present season was indeed
divine –the flowers of spring
blossomed
^
bloomed
in the
hedgeswhile those of summer were al
ready in bud–I dis was not disturbedby
thoughts thatduring the preceeding
year pressed upon me not withstand
ing my endeavours to throw them off with an invincible burthen.
Henry a rejoiced
im in my gaietyand
sincerely sympathizedin my
joy feelings –he exer
ted himself to amuse me, while he expressed
the feelingsthat al filled his
mind
^
soul .The
resources of his mind on this occasion
were truly astonishing. As we rested during
the sultry heat of noon he invented
hisconversation was full of imagination
and very often, in imitation of the persi
an&Arabic writers, he invented tales
of
great
^
wonderful
fancy and interrest.At other
times he repeated my favourite poems
or drew me out into argumentswhich
he supported with great ingenuity.
We returned
^
to our colledge
on a sunday –the pea
santswere dancingand every one we
met appeared joyfuland happy –my
own spirits were highand I bounded
along with a feelings of
hilarity unbound
ed
unbridled
joy and hilarity.
